descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course examines the relationship between law and the distribution of power in society, with a particular emphasis on law and social change in the United States. Readings will be drawn from the social sciences and history, as well as selected court cases that raise critical questions about the role of race, gender, and sexual orientation in American society. Among the material we will examine are the documents made public in the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri. Students should be aware that some of this material is graphic and disturbing.

Students will be called on to discuss readings on a rotating basis. Students will write four short essays that critically engage the readings, some of which will be used for in class exercises.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn about the relationship between law, inequality, and social change in American society. They will learn to read social scientific analyses of law, important court cases, and original legal materials. They will learn how to apply a sociological analysis to contemporary debates in law and policy.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The only class meetings are two 90-minute class meetings a week. There are no discussion sections. Class sessions are meant to provide an opportunity for active engagement with assigned readings. Students are expected to come to class prepared to discuss assigned material. Groups of students will be assigned responsibility for leading class discussions on a rotating basis.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Performance will be evaluated based on class participation and attendance and four short writing assignments. These will be weighted as follows: 1) Attendance and class participation: 2 points for each class attended up to a total of 30 points; and up to 20 points for contributing to class discussion. 2) 25 points for each of 4 writing assignments.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
We will read three books:
William Haltom and Michael McCann, Distorting the Law: Politics, Media, and the Litigation Crisis (U of Chicago Press 2004) ISBN: 9780226314648
Charles Epp, Making Rights Real: Activists, Bureaucrats, and the Creation of the Legalistic State (U of Chicago Press (2009) ISBN: 9780226211657
Michelle Alexander, The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness (The New Press 2012). ISBN: 1595581030

Books can be ordered through Amazon.com.

We will also use readings from a coursepack available at Quartet Printing at 825 Clark Street, Evanston.
